sub_title: Assistant Professor of English Literature at Radboud University Nijmegen
summary:
I am an Assistant Professor of English Literature at Radboud University Nijmegen (Department of Modern Languages & Cultures). My research interests include theatrical engagements with Brexit and the European project, Irish drama, postcolonial cultural memory, national identity formation, and modernist poetry. 

I was awarded the 2015 Irish Society for Theatre Research (ISTR) New Scholars' Prize for my research on postcolonial mythological plays, and in April 2017, I received my PhD (cum laude) for a thesis on cultural memory and national identity formation at the Dublin Gate Theatre. I was the Assistant Director of the NWO-funded Gate Theatre Research Network (2018-2021) and the recipient of the 2017 Education Award for Best Junior Lecturer in the Faculty of Arts at Radboud University. In February/March 2018, I held a Visiting Research Fellowship at the Moore Institute (National University of Ireland, Galway).

My book 'Avant-Garde Nationalism at the Dublin Gate Theatre, 1928-1940' was published by Syracuse University Press ( https://press.syr.edu/supressbooks/3470/avant-garde-nationalism-at-the-dublin-gate-theatre-1928-1940/ ) in 2021. In 2023, I received the RICH Outstanding Research Award.

http://www.ruudvandenbeuken.nl (Dutch)

projects.title: Public Lectures and Workshops, 2022-
projects.description:
● Gave a public lecture titled '"Like looking in a mirror and seeing everything a touch crooked”: Midhir and Etáin in Post-Revivalist Irish Drama', Keltisch Colloquium, Utrecht, 18 March 2023.

● Gave a public lecture on the representation of gender, sexuality, and trauma in Joelle Taylor's poetry for the Beyond the Book project, Openbare Bibliotheek Gelderland Zuid, Nijmegen, 12 October 2022.

● Ran a workshop on the cultural representation of LGBTQI+ identities, Nijmegen Taalhoofdstad, 10 May 2022.

● Co-wrote and co-presented an educational video on the legacy of Christopher Marlowe's 'Edward II', Nijmegen Taalhoofdstad, 10 May 2022. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lkRGriQhxik

● Gave a public mini-lecture and hosted the pre-programme show for Oostpool's 'Edward II - The Gay King', LUX Nijmegen, 4 March 2022.

projects.title: Public Lectures, Workshops, and Poetry Readings 2018-2021
projects.description:
● Gave a Pre-University College master class on the 'Brexit Shorts' ('"Theatervlogs" als politieke kunst?') for secondary school pupils, Radboud University Nijmegen, 7 December 2021.

● Gave a public lecture on "Staging the Free State: New Irish drama at the Dublin Gate Theatre", Queen's University Belfast, Irish Studies Research Seminar series (online), 10 May 2021. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b0bXqWhuCgo

● Wrote and presented a series of five mini-lectures on the Gate Theatre's history, November-December 2020. 
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLe9q_T-KUuswZDkxQrJZuO2TCsKHrkizR

● Gave a public lecture on the obscenity trial regarding Allen Ginsberg's 'Howl', Boekenfeest, Nijmegen, 7 March 2020.

● Gave a public lecture (with Casper Kirkels) on "De Grote Brexit Show", Jonge Democraten, Nijmegen, 28 October 2019.

● Read from own work at the launch of 'Het Liegend Konijn' 2019 autumn issue, Boekhandel Bosch&deJong, Rotterdam, 20 October 2019.

● Ran a workshop on "Courtroom Drama: The Politics and Poetics of Staging Trials", Law and Art symposium, Radboud University Nijmegen, 12 June 2019.

● Gave a lecture on Winston Churchill, Culture on Campus screening of 'Darkest Hour' (2017), Radboud University Nijmegen, 27 February 2019.

● Gave a lecture on British parliament and Brexit, Great Anglo-Saxon Gobblers study association, Radboud University Nijmegen, 15 February 2019.

● Gave a lecture on Mohsin Hamid's 'Exit West' (2017), British and Irish Fiction Today post-academic course, Radboud University Nijmegen, 12 December 2018.

● Ran a workshop on modernist literature, Dr.-Knippenbergcollege, Helmond, 4 June 2018.
Chaired the GNE Nuffic Speaking Awards jury, Dr.-Knippenbergcollege, Helmond, 22 March 2018.

projects.title: Conference Papers 2016
projects.description:
●  “‘How can you call it a nation?’: The Ascendancy and the Free State in Christine Longford’s Mr. Jiggins of Jigginstown”. Presented at the "The Irish Protestant Playwrights" conference, National University of Ireland, Galway, 1-3 June 2016.

● “‘When the Irish were cave-men’: Contestations of Nativist Discourse and Rural Modernity in Post-Independence Irish Drama”. Presented at the "Tradition and/or Modernity" conference, Radboud University Nijmegen, 26-27 May 2016.

contributors.headline: Assistant Professor of English Literature at Radboud University Nijmegen

projects.title: Conference Papers and Organisation 2015
projects.description:
● “Let’s Give the Mantle of Harlequin a Brush: Stimulating Research on the Dublin Gate Theatre Archive at Northwestern University”. Presented at the Performing the Archive conference, National University of Ireland, Galway, 22-24 July
2015.

● "‘Partly Pirate and Wholly Patriot’: The Liminal Identity of Queen Grace O’Malley in David Sears’s 'Graine of the Ships' (1933)". Presented at the "Beyond Ireland: Boundaries, Passages, Transitions" EFACIS conference, University of Palermo, 3-6 June 2015.

● "A Future Femme Fatale: Prospective Memory Structures in Micheál MacLiammóir's 'Diarmuid and Grainne' (1928)". Presented at the "Irish Theatrical Diaspora" conference, The Dublin Gate Theatre, 30 April - 1 May 2015.

● "'Leave the Dean in the obscurity he deserves': Jonathan Swift and the Construction of National Memories in the Earl of Longford's 'Yahoo' (1933)". Presented at the "Irish Studies and the Dynamics of Memory: Transitions and Transformations" conference, Radboud University Nijmegen, 31 March - 2 April 2015.

● Co-organiser of the "Irish Studies and the Dynamics of Memory: Transitions and Transformations" conference, Radboud University Nijmegen, 31 March - 2 April 2015.

● "'My blessing on the pistol and the powder and the ball!': Prospective Memories of Landlord Murders in the Earl of Longford's Ascendancy (1935)". Presented at the "Performing Famine Memory: Irish Theatre and the Great Hunger" symposium, National University of Ireland, Galway, 12-13 February 2015.

● Co-organiser of the "Reading and Readerships: Evolutions of the Literary Experience" OSL Ravenstein PhD seminar, University of Amsterdam, 22-23 January 2015.

projects.title: Conference Papers and Organisation 2014
projects.description:
● "National Identity Formation at the Dublin Gate Theatre, 1928-1940". Presented at "The Poetics and Politics of National Identity" OSL PhD Newsroom, University of Amsterdam, 28 November 2014.

● Co-organiser of the "Moving Humanities 2014" Graduate School of the Humanities PhD conference, Radboud University Nijmegen, 23 October 2014.

● “'Ten thousand years look down on you, ten thousand more are waiting expectantly': Memory, Warfare, and Irishness in David Sears’s 'Juggernaut' (1928)". Presented at the "Embodying/Disembodying Ireland" IASIL conference, Université Charles de Gaulle – Lille 3, 14-18 July 2014.

contributors.headline: Assistant Professor of English Literature at Radboud University Nijmegen

projects.title: Conference Papers and Organisation 2013
projects.description:
● "'Forget you’re in a Dublin slum and sing me a song': Contrasting Urban and Rural Irishness at the Gate Theatre, 1930-1940." Presented at the "The Irish and the City" ISTR conference, University of London (Birkbeck), 1-2 November 2013.

● "MacLiammóir’s Minstrel and Johnston’s Morality: Cultural Memories of the Easter Rising at the Dublin Gate Theatre, 1929-1932." Presented at the "Towards 2016: Old and New Irelands" EFACIS conference, National University of Ireland, Galway, 5-8 June 2013.

● "'The Gate Influence on Dublin Theatre': Reassessing the Historiography of Edwards-MacLiammóir Productions." Presented at the "Ireland Past and Present" ACIS conference, DePaul University, Chicago, and Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, 10-13 April 2013.

● Co-organiser of the "Global Legacies of the Great Irish Famine: Transnational and Interdisciplinary Perspectives" conference, Radboud University Nijmegen, 25-28 March 2013.

contributors.headline: Assistant Professor of English Literature at Radboud University Nijmegen

projects.title: Conference Papers 2012
projects.description:
● “‘Something Left Over from the Eighteenth Century, Undergoing a Slow Process of Decay’: Teleological Redundancy and Civil War Trauma in Mary Manning’s 'Youth’s the Season –?' (1931)”. Presented at English Staff & Postgraduate Seminar Series, Trinity College Dublin, 31 October 2012. 

● "‘Conscious in All Its Activities of Doing a Service to the Nation’?: Avant-garde Patriotism and (Inter)nationalist Identities at the Dublin Gate Theatre, 1928-1934". Presented at the "Perform, or Else! New Perspectives on Theatre Studies" ISTR conference, National University of Ireland, Galway, 26-28 October 2012. 

● “Touwtrekken om die goeie ouwe Sam, of: hoe het Dublin Gate Theater de Frans-Ierse strijd om Becketts nationaliteit postuum beslechtte”. Presented at the Moving Humanities seminar, Radboud University Nijmegen, 18 October 2012. 

● “‘Ireland is one long unending problem’: Memory, Modernity, and Inter)nationalist Identities at the Dublin Gate Theatre”. Presented at the PhD Seminar in Irish Studies, KU Leuven, 3-7 September 2012.

● “Invoking and Exorcising ‘the Famished Mouth’: Micheál MacLiammóir’s Teleological Performance of Haunting Memories and Adoptive Identities in 'All for Hecuba' (1946)”. Presented at the "Famine, Memory, and the Irish Diaspora: Migrants, Remembrance, Performance" symposium, University of Limerick, 22 March 2012.

contributors.headline: Assistant Professor of English Literature at Radboud University Nijmegen

projects.title: Conference Papers 2010-2011
projects.description:
● “‘It is the business of the Theatre to be theatrical’: Modernist Poetics, Cultural Trauma, and the Performance of Famine Memory at the Gate Theatre”. Presented at the "Irish Literatures: Conflict and Resolution" IASIL conference, KU Leuven, 18-22 July 2011. 

● “‘Preach to Arouse, and Warn, and Watch, and Encourage!’: Cultural Memory and Diegetic Structures in James Clarence Mangan’s Famine Poems”. Presented at the "Irish Literatures and Culture: New and Old Knowledges" IASIL conference, National University of Ireland, Maynooth, 26-30 July 2010.

profile_positions.description:
Faculty of Arts, Department of Modern Languages & Cultures 
● Courses: British Culture and History (2019/20), British Literature and Culture of the 19th and 20th Century (2019/20 - 2022/23), Beyond Britishness: The Construction of Identities in Literature and Culture (2019/20 - 2022/23), Reading Literature (2020/21 - 2022/23), Staging Politics: Identity and Representation in Post-Brexit Drama (MA, 2021/22 - 2022/23)
● Guest lectures: British Culture and History (2021/22 - 2022/23), English Studies Now (2019/20), Irish Literature and the Construction of Cultural Identities (MA, 2019/20 - 2020/21), Contemporary Debates: Culture in Crisis / Crisis in Culture (MA, 2020/21), Overdracht en educatie van kunst en cultuur (MA, 2022/23)
● PhD supervision: Dirk Visser, 'Plague Re-enacted: Drama as Cultural Memory of AIDS'

company.name: Gate Theatre Research Network (Radboud University Nijmegen)

profile_positions.company: Gate Theatre Research Network (Radboud University Nijmegen)
profile_positions.description:
The Gate Theatre Research Network (GTRN) is a collaboration between scholars based in the Netherlands, Ireland, the UK, the Czech Republic, France, Norway, and the United States. Its purpose is to study the the Dublin Gate Theatre in various international contexts by analysing its engagement with cosmopolitanism, cultural exchange and identity formation. In doing so, it aims to uncover marginalised histories and promote the wider use of archival resources, such as the holdings at the Charles Deering McCormick Library (Northwestern University) and the ongoing digitisation project at the James Hardiman Library (NUI Galway).

http://www.ru.nl/gatetheatre
